<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Added support for /docs/latest
username_0: This is a first attempt at supporting /docs/latest.

Although I think this works for now it might make more sense to develop a slightly more complex (but powerful) feature: version aliases.

This would allow me to avoid to show in the dropdown menu `Vx.x.x` and then `latest` (as a separate version) and instead show a single entry named `Vx.x.x (latest)`.

Let me know if this is good enough for now or if you have other ideas on how to handle the aliasing.

Closes #17
<issue_comment>username_1: What's the status on this?
<issue_comment>username_0: I did a number of changes and I think this is now ready to be merged.

Latest version is never shown in versions lists, but it can be used as an alias in the urls.

Also when accessing the latest version (as `/docs/latest`) every dropdown now displays the correct latest release tag as selected.

@allevo, @username_1, please double check if this looks like the expected behaviour to you before I proceed with the merge.

[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'samajammin', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2021-10-12T22:35:58Z', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': '*To make our work more accessible and to foster more community collaboration, our team publishes an overview of our quarterly roadmap goals. See last quarter's roadmap here: #3446.*

**Greetings fellow Ethereans!**

Happy Hacktoberfest! [Our vision with ethereum.org](https://ethereum.org/en/about/) continues to be to create the best portal for Ethereum's growing community, and to serve as the front door to Ethereum for millions of new visitors each month. Here's a look at our major Q4 initiatives to advance this vision.

##  🚀 Enable a CLR.fund quadratic funding round on layer 2

As [mentioned in our Q3 closing update](https://github.com/ethereum/ethereum-org-website/issues/3446#issuecomment-937394528), we didn't achieve our goal to launch a funding round on mainnet. Our primary goal this quarter is to enable one. We plan to get [this project](https://github.com/ethereum/clrfund) across the finish line by merging our changes upstream into the [CLR.fund repo](https://github.com/clrfund/monorepo) and to help enable a community to launch a funding round on Arbitrum One leveraging the features we've contributed.

While not directly related to ethereum.org, we're hoping this effort will increase the cultural momentum around ecosystem funding for public goods as well as demonstrate, popularize and diversify CLRs as a use case for communities across the ecosystem.

Follow along with progress at [our GitHub repo](https://github.com/ethereum/clrfund) and [play around with a deployed application here](https://eth2clrfund.netlify.app/#/) - we'll keep running test rounds on RinkArby as we approach mainnet readiness! Join the [CLR.fund community Discord server](https://discord.gg/sy7kN97Mqv) to get involved.

## 🔀 Rebrand "Eth2"

The highly anticipated network upgrade known as "[the merge](https://ethereum.org/en/eth2/merge/)" is approaching. Once that upgrade takes place, there will no longer be two distinct Ethereum networks or concepts of "Eth1" and "Eth2" - there will just be the Ethereum network we all know in love.

In preparation for this event, we need to revamp our [Eth2 resources](https://ethereum.org/en/eth2/) in order to explain this evolution, reduce confusion and prevent FUD within the community. This quarter we'll reorganize these resources and update the terminology on these pages to best reflect the reality of these Ethereum network upgrades. This may involve restructuring the [Eth2 bug bounty program](https://ethereum.org/en/eth2/get-involved/bug-bounty/) and [ways to get involved](https://ethereum.org/en/eth2/get-involved/) by consolidating them into more general Ethereum resources.

## 🥩 Make staking easier

Running a node and participating as a validator is a critical component of getting involved as an Ethereum community member. We want to continue to make this process as simple and easy as possible for anyone to set up.

We'll add content resources and update user flows (both on [ethereum.org](https://ethereum.org/en/) and [launchpad.ethereum.org](https://launchpad.ethereum.org/en/)) to improve the UX for anyone interested in staking, including walkthroughs on how to first set up a staking node on a risk-free testnet.

## 🎓 Revamp the Learn page

There is a lot to learn in the Ethereum ecosystem. Currently ethereum.org provides an ever-growing list of disconnected pages that users must piece together independently. Our long-lived ["Learn" page](https://ethereum.org/en/learn/) provides a scattered list of topics without much rhyme or reason behind the sequence or importance of these topics.

We'll redesign this page and the "Learn" site navigation to improve our content hierarchy for users and create more structured pathways to learning Ethereum that folks can navigate based on their areas of interest and current level of knowledge.

## 🔍 Improve site search

At the moment our search functionality isn't working as well as we'd like - specifically regarding [how we index our content](https://github.com/ethereum/ethereum-org-website/issues/2764) and [how we rank content in search results](https://github.com/ethereum/ethereum-org-website/issues/3842) - so we'll address these issues to improve the search experience for everyone.

It's now been over 2 years since we launched our [Translation Program initiative](https://ethereum.org/en/contributing/translation-program/) in 2019. Since inception, over 2,000 community members have contributed, translating a total of 2.8 million words! ethereum.org is now [available in 37 different languages](https://ethereum.org/en/languages/).

We plan to invest more to acknowledge this incredible community of volunteers from across the globe. We'll build out a Translation Leaderboard, a Translator Certification Plan and additional content to recognize our amazing contributors.

We added technical improvements to our codebase (https://github.com/ethereum/ethereum-org-website/pull/4441) in order to support the [recent release](https://blog.ethereum.org/2021/10/04/translation-program-update/) of new content for translation & overhaul of our content management.

We ran two community calls with over 230 attendees between them. These calls provide us with a space to share what we’re working on, collect feedback & answer question from the community, as well as highlight community contributions to acknowledge volunteers for their work.

1. [ethereum.org](http://ethereum.org/) code & content
2. [ethereum.org](http://ethereum.org) translations

We consider these calls to be a huge success, with over 50 attendees in each, increasing community ownership & feedback for our product. We plan to continue these on a monthly basis in 2022.

[Join our Discord](https://discord.gg/CetY6Y4) to receive notifications about upcoming community calls & office hours. We'll also announce them on [our Twitter](https://twitter.com/ethdotorg).

While we had some productive brainstorming & planning sessions around how we can improve website accessibility, we unfortunately didn’t ship any improvements to the site outside of miscellaneous bug fixes & UI/UX improvements. We’re hoping to tackle an accessibility audit in Q1 2022.

Do you have any specific suggestions? Would you like to contribute to this? We'd love to hear from you - please [create an issue](https://github.com/ethereum/ethereum-org-website/issues/new/choose).

## 🦄 Revamp the Community page

We completely restructured our Ethereum community content & redesigned a new community hub with the overall goal of empowering users to participate in the Ethereum ecosystem more easily.

We shipped five new pages:
- [The community hub](https://ethereum.org/en/community/) is designed to help navigate people to the correct place to meet their community goals.
- [Online communities](https://ethereum.org/en/community/online/) organizes forums, chatrooms & other online resources that people can join to find their tribe.
- [Events](https://ethereum.org/en/community/events/) consolidates Ethereum events & meetups into one easy to find, canonical location.
[Truncated]

We continue to progress with candidate interviews & expect to extend a job offer by the end of the month, so stay tuned for an announcement around this. We’re beyond excited to bring a full-time designer onboard to accelerate our product development.

Exciting progress on this front - we hired a web developer (hi @nhsz) to build out this website redesign. Nico is working with ESP’s designer & operations team to bring their vision to reality & has been progressing on an implementation.

To close this ticket, we also need to update links in the website header, which are defined in different repositories. Since the Ember website consists of many parts, there are many places where these URLs are mentioned.

Here is what I found:
1. [ember-styleguide](https://github.com/ember-learn/ember-styleguide/blob/f03492c4adc171daabea12d1d694f46ee1b47529/addon/constants/links.js#L5) repository defines links for the [Ember](https://emberjs.com), [Ember Guides](https://guides.emberjs.com) and [Ember CLI Guides](https://cli.emberjs.com) headers.

@username_0 please, let me know if you have any concerns with updating links in [ember-styleguide](https://github.com/ember-learn/ember-blog/blob/6ba802ed0e575d57ca6774fba3059d9a4a1822dc/source/_header.html.erb#L18-L20)? It might  be not the best place to apply routing optimizations (to remove the redirect) but definitely the simplest.

Alternatives will be:
1. Configure routing to make https://guides.emberjs.com and https://api.emberjs.com as the default routes for the latest release (probably, the best option if there are no technical challenges with this).
2. Keep everything as is and close the issue.
3. Add the `/release/` path to URLs on the application side (probably, the worst option).
